IS-Retail is not your only option, but it’s the most straightforward for KIT purchasing. In standard S/4HANA (without IS-Retail or EWM), there are limited native options—however, you can explore workarounds using BOMs, subcontracting, or custom PO item structures. And yes, IS-Retail typically requires a separate license.

To your question "Is there any other standard SAP solution for KIT purchasing?", the answer is Yes, but with limitations. In standard S/4HANA (non-Retail, non-EWM), you can explore:

You create a PO for the KIT (finished product) and define its components in a BOM. Upon goods receipt, the system can post stock for components if configured correctly.
Limitation: This is designed for external assembly, not direct KIT purchase. It assumes the vendor assembles the KIT.

Limitation: Requires development and doesn’t update stock automatically per component.

To your next question, "Is IS-Retail the only option or are there workarounds?", the answer is IS-Retail is the only standard SAP module that natively supports KIT purchasing with component explosion and stock update per component. However, if IS-Retail is not available, you can use subcontracting workaround with BOMs and PO type adjustments. Consider custom development to simulate KIT explosion at PO level and update stock per component. Explore third-party add-ons or SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) extensions for KIT handling.

entry.title: Re: Is Purchasing Group Field Locked in PRs Created from...
entry.content:
Yes, your understanding is correct: in standard SAP S/4HANA, Purchase Requisitions (PRs) created from maintenance orders inherit key fields like the Purchasing Group and Header Description, and these fields are intentionally locked to preserve data consistency.

Why these fields are locked is because, Purchasing Group and Header Description are derived directly from the maintenance order during PR creation. SAP locks these fields in the PR to ensure synchronization between the maintenance order and the procurement process. This behavior is part of standard integration logic between Plant Maintenance (PM) and Materials Management (MM), designed to avoid data mismatches.

Standard configuration does not allow editing these fields in PRs generated from maintenance orders. The fields are controlled by the order type and maintenance planning parameters, not by MM settings. Even with full authorization, SAP restricts editing to maintain integrity between the order and its dependent documents.

If your business process requires editing these fields post-creation, you can explore BADI ME_PROCESS_REQ_CUST to allow conditional editing of PR fields. Implement logic to unlock or override the Purchasing Group or Header Description based on user role or document source.

Create a workflow that allows authorized users to request changes to locked fields. Upon approval, a background job or enhancement updates the PR.

entry.title: Re: Batch-specific UoM Proportion/product unit of measure...
entry.content:
Dear Mr. Abdelrehman,
You are getting this error VL382 occurs because SAP does not allow switching to a proportion/product unit of measure (like GON) in delivery processing when the sales order uses a base unit (like KG), unless specific configuration and master data conditions are met.

The reason for this error VL382,
The error message “Proportion/product unit of measure GON invalid for item 000010” (VL382) typically appears when the sales order uses a base unit of measure (KG) or the delivery attempts to use a batch-specific or proportion unit (GON).

SAP restricts switching to proportion/product units in delivery because, There are preceding or subsequent documents (e.g., sales order already created in KG). The sales unit is not a proportion/product unit. The batch-specific UoM conversion is not properly maintained in the material master or classification.

It works in MM (PO/MIGO) but Not in SD (Delivery) because, In MM (MIGO), allows flexible UoM conversion during goods receipt if the batch-specific UoM is correctly maintained, but in SD (VL01N), SAP enforces stricter rules for the sales order UoM must match the delivery UoM, unless the material is configured to allow proportion/product UoM usage. The batch-specific UoM must be active and correctly linked via classification and characteristics.

To fix the error we can do following as mentioned below.

To resolve VL382 and allow delivery in GON,

1. Check Material Master Configuration
Ensure the material has GON defined as a batch-specific UoM.
Maintain the conversion ratio between KG and GON in the classification using characteristics.

2. Validate Classification Setup:
Assign the correct class type 023 (Batch) to the material.
Include a characteristic that defines the conversion factor between KG and GON.
Ensure the batch master data includes this characteristic value.

3. Enable Proportion/Product UoM in Sales Order:
If possible, create the sales order using GON as the sales unit.
Alternatively, configure the material to allow automatic conversion during delivery.

4. Check Delivery Item Settings:
In VL01N, ensure the delivery item references the correct batch with valid conversion data.
Use batch split if needed to handle multiple UoMs.

5. Custom UoM Mapping:
Since GON is a custom UoM, verify that it is fully mapped and recognized in SAP's UoM tables and conversion logic.

Hope the above explanation is helpful.

entry.title: Re: CO15: Production order confirmation at header level w...
entry.content:
Yes, the issue you're facing is linked to how SAP handles confirmation for QM operations. When a routing includes operations with control key QM01, the system does not populate the Shift field in CO15 because QM operations are not designed for standard PP confirmations.

Why the shift field is empty for QM01 Operations is because, QM01 control key is typically used for Quality Management operations, which are not meant to be confirmed via CO15 or CO11N. These operations are handled through inspection lots and results recording, not through PP confirmation transactions. As a result, SAP suppresses certain fields like Shift, Work Center, and sometimes even personnel data in CO15 when QM01 is present in the routing.

When using PP control keys like YBP1 or PP01, the system expects standard production confirmations. These operations are fully integrated with CO15/CO11N, and fields like Shift are populated based on work center scheduling and shift definitions

Some possible workarounds are

Separate QM01 operations from PP operations in the routing. Confirm PP operations via CO15 and handle QM operations via inspection lot processing. Create a custom control key (e.g., ZQM1) that mimics QM01 but allows confirmation via CO15. This requires careful configuration to avoid disrupting QM processes.

Here the most important point is forcing confirmation of QM operations via CO15 may violate standard SAP process flows and affect inspection lot handling. Always validate with your QM consultant or business process owner before modifying control keys or confirmation logic.

entry.title: S/4HANA Cloud Public Security now integrates with leading SIEM solutions
entry.content:
Cloud Security Just Got Easier: S/4HANA Cloud Public Security now integrates with leading SIEM solutions

Introduction

We have some exciting news to share, which emphasizes the strategic importance of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and delivers upon our promise to strengthen cloud security: our security relevant APIs are now integrated with three major SIEM platforms – Microsoft Sentinel, Splunk, and Security Bridge.

This integration opens up new possibilities for customers to connect their SAP Cloud environments with their existing security operations, enabling faster threat detection, streamlined compliance, and better visibility across hybrid landscapes.

Three Use Cases, One API Strategy

The security APIs in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition are designed to support three major use cases:

  • SIEM (Security Information and Event Management): For real-time event monitoring and threat detection.
  • SSPM (SaaS Security Posture Management): To assess and maintain your system’s security configuration.
  • CASB (Cloud Access Security Broker): For monitoring user behavior and enforcing security policies.

Even within the shared responsibility model for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, these use cases will give you valuable insight into your security posture, enable a comprehensive security monitoring and will help you to enforce your security policies across your entire system landscape, including your cloud applications.

The Corner Stone: Security Audit Log (SAL) API

As mentioned, security in the cloud is a shared effort. SAP, as the cloud provider, handles infrastructure-level protection – think database security, OS patching, and physical data center controls. But what happens inside the application – user access, configuration, and monitoring – is the customer’s responsibility.

That’s where the SAL API comes in. It provides direct access to the Security Audit Log, capturing key events like successful and failed logins, transaction starts, or authorization checks. These logs are essential for understanding what’s happening in customers applications and to identify potential threats as soon as they occur.

Traditionally, SIEM tools have focused on infrastructure logs. Without application-level visibility, you’re missing half the picture. The SAL API bridges that gap. It’s a RESTful API delivering data in JSON format, ready for integration with modern security platforms. You can filter by event type, time range, and more – making it suitable for real-time monitoring, forensic analysis, and audit reporting.

The SAL API is your window into the application layer – and a key enabler for fulfilling your responsibilities under the shared security model.

More Than Just SAL: Event-Based vs. Configuration APIs

But there is more for a comprehensive picture of your security posture than just capturing SAL events. SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition offers a rich set of additional security-relevant APIs, and it’s important to understand how they map to the different use cases.

Event-Based APIs (for SIEM and CASB)

These APIs deliver real-time or historical event data and are ideal for SIEM systems that correlate and analyze logs for threat detection and incident response:

  • Security Audit Log API: Captures system-level events like logins, transaction starts, and authorization checks.
  • Read Access Log API: Records user access to sensitive data objects, helping detect unauthorized access.
  • Business User Change API: Tracks changes to user master data, such as name updates or role assignments.
  • Business Role Change API: Logs modifications to business roles, including who made the change and when.

These APIs are essential for building audit trails, supporting forensic investigations, and maintaining compliance.

Configuration & Static APIs (for SSPM)

SSPM tools focus on the current security posture of your system – how it’s configured and whether it aligns with best practices. These APIs provide read access to configuration data and help detect misconfigurations or unused entities:

  • Business User & Role Read APIs: Provides current state information about users and roles in the system.
  • Communication User, System & Arrangement APIs: Offers insights into how external systems and users are connected and authenticated.
  • HTTP Protection Configuration APIs: Helps monitoring and validating content security policies and allowlist configurations.
  • Trusted Certificates API: Lists certificates used for secure communication, helping ensure encryption and trust relationships are properly maintained.

Together, these APIs will provide you with all the information you need in order to support the three use cases mentioned above. But how do these APIs fit into a more general security strategy, beyond your business applications. That’s where our partners come in.

Partner Integrations: It’s Happening

We’re super excited that our partners have reacted quickly on the recently published APIs and have already integrated SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition into their security solutions.  Microsoft Sentinel, Splunk, and Security Bridge have built integrations, starting with the SAL API, so customers can get started quickly – no custom development required.

If you’re heading to SAP TechEd, you’ll hear more about these integrations and how they fit into SAP’s broader security strategy. It’s not just a feature drop – it’s part of a bigger story about making cloud security smarter and more connected.

Final Thoughts

The SAL API and its companion interfaces mark a turning point in how customers can manage security in SAP S/4HANA Cloud. With native SIEM integrations, a clear shared responsibility model, and growing partner support, it’s never been easier to take control of your cloud security.

entry.title: Re: Request for Option to Create Single PM Notification f...
entry.content:
HI;

n standard SAP PM, the notification creation process allows only one equipment per notification. There is no built-in option to select or enter multiple equipment during notification creation.

Possible Workarounds:

Use Functional Location: If the equipment share a common functional location, create the notification for the location and mention the equipment in the long text or tasks.

Custom Enhancement: Develop a custom screen or program using ABAP that allows multiple equipment selection and creates a composite notification.

Use Additional Fields or Long Text: Include other equipment references in the notification long text or custom fields, though this limits automation and reporting.

Link Multiple Notifications to One Work Order: If the goal is to perform maintenance on multiple equipment together, create separate notifications and link them to a single work order.

Due to SAP’s limitation in creating a single PM Notification for multiple equipment, the following approach is recommended:

Shared Functional Location (FL): Group related equipment under a common functional location. Create the PM Notification for the FL and mention the individual equipment in the long text or tasks.

PM Order Object Linking: Create separate notifications for each equipment and link them to a single PM Order. This enables centralized planning, execution, and reporting.

Benefits:

Maintains SAP standard structure

Enables equipment-level reporting

Provides flexibility in resource planning and execution

entry.title: Syntax error cannot change itab inside LOOP AT itab GROUP BY ...
entry.content:
I get this syntax error (the message is different depending on the ABAP version - NB: the message ID is MESSAGEGAC in table TRMSG):

  • ABAP 7.40: You may not delete or overwrite table "ITAB" within a LOOP over itself. that internal optimization can take place.
  • ABAP 7.58: The table "ITAB" cannot be deleted or overwritten within a loop across itself.

It happens in the line 6 (DELETE itab) of this code, used to delete the lines which are not of type 'E':

DATA(itab) = VALUE bapirettab( ( type = 'S' ) ( type = 'S' ) ( type = 'E' ) ).
LOOP AT itab REFERENCE INTO DATA(line)
     GROUP BY line->type.
  IF line->type <> 'E'.
    LOOP AT GROUP line TRANSPORTING NO FIELDS.
      DELETE itab INDEX sy-tabix.
    ENDLOOP.
  ENDIF.
ENDLOOP.

NB: of course, this code may be reduced to one line, its only goal is to support the question, my original code is much more complex.

Thanks.

Sandra

For information, I did other tests with other statements to change the internal table:

  1. The same syntax error happens if these statements are used: APPEND, INSERT, FREE, REFRESH, CLEAR itab, SORT.
  2. This other syntax error may happen if MODIFY itab FROM VALUE #( ) is used instead of DELETE: "The implicit variants "DELETE itab." and "MODIFY itab FROM wa." cannot be used in a "LOOP AT itab ... USING KEY keyname ..." (message MESSAGEGJI in the table TRMSG).
  3. If the table is modified indirectly (via a subroutine, a reference, a field symbol or whatever), a short dump happens instead (TABLE_ILLEGAL_STATEMENT, TABLE_FREE_IN_LOOP, etc.)
  4. The only case which works is this one: MODIFY itab FROM VALUE #( ) INDEX idx.

entry.title: Re: Syntax error cannot change itab inside LOOP AT itab GROUP BY ...
entry.content:
The syntax error is because "The internal table itab cannot be modified in the group loop [...]" (LOOP AT itab, GROUP BY | ABAP Keyword Documentation).

NB: the sentence is completed with "unless the addition WITHOUT MEMBERS is specified", because in that case the group keys are determined before the loop starts (grouping phase), then the loop starts on the group keys (Group Loop phase), so any modification to itab is valid because internally it's no more a loop on the itab lines (it was one only during the grouping phase), it's a loop on the group keys.

Now, the solution is simply to delay the modifications after the loop. There are two solutions:

Solution 1

During the loop, you need to save what is to be done to the internal table in a journal.

NB: it's important to delete from the end otherwise you would delete the wrong lines because the table indexes of the lines after the deleted line are changed.

DATA(itab) = VALUE bapirettab( ( type = 'S' ) ( type = 'S' ) ( type = 'E' ) ).
DATA itab_tabix TYPE TABLE OF sytabix.       "<====== add
LOOP AT itab REFERENCE INTO DATA(line)
     GROUP BY line->type.
   IF line->type <> 'E'.
    LOOP AT GROUP line TRANSPORTING NO FIELDS.
      INSERT sy-tabix INTO TABLE itab_tabix. "<====== add
    ENDLOOP.
  ENDIF.
ENDLOOP.
SORT itab_tabix BY table_line DESCENDING.    "<====== add these 4 lines
LOOP AT itab_tabix INTO DATA(tabix).
  DELETE itab INDEX tabix.
ENDLOOP.

EDIT enhanced solution proposed by @wridgeu : SORT not needed if using STEP -1, instead of the 4 last lines:

LOOP AT itab_tabix INTO DATA(tabix) STEP -1.
  DELETE itab INDEX tabix.
ENDLOOP.

 

Solution 2

If the internal table is small you may duplicate the internal table, do the changes immediately to the duplicated, and after the loop transfer back the values to the original internal table.

DATA(itab) = VALUE bapirettab( ( type = 'S' ) ( type = 'S' ) ( type = 'E' ) ).
DATA(itab_duplicate) = itab.                "<====== add
LOOP AT itab REFERENCE INTO DATA(line)
     GROUP BY line->type.
   IF line->type <> 'E'.
    LOOP AT GROUP line TRANSPORTING NO FIELDS.
      DELETE itab_duplicate INDEX sy-tabix. "<====== add
    ENDLOOP.
  ENDIF.
ENDLOOP.
itab = itab_duplicate.                      "<====== add

I created a SAP case and got the answer that "SAP built the dual-status control for traceability between billing and approval processes." After one user has rejected the document via the workflow, the requestor (billing clerk) has to reject manually via the Fiori App F2875 to reprocess it.

Though, I don't get why the automatic rejection in one phase would be a problem for the "traceability".

I did a modification of the standard to change the behavior (use it at your own risk).

With this modification, after the document has been rejected via the workflow (VBRK-APM_APPROVAL_STATUS), the document status (VBRK-PBD_STATUS) moves automatically from the status finalized to rejected.

I created an implicit enhancement at the end of the function module RV_INVOICE_SET_APPROVAL_ACTION with this code:

    " If reject by workflow (APM_APPROVAL_STATUS is the workflow status)
    IF     is_vbrk-vbtyp               = 'PBD' "preliminary
       AND is_vbrk-pbd_status          = if_sd_bil_constants=>co_pbd_status_finalized
       AND is_vbrk-apm_approval_status = if_sd_apm_approval=>co_approval_status-rejected.
      " Set VBRK-PBD_STATUS = REJECT status via tRFC call
      " to avoid conflict with current update VBRK-APM_APPROVAL_STATUS
      CALL FUNCTION 'Z_REJECT_PBD_STATUS'
        IN BACKGROUND TASK
        EXPORTING iv_vbeln = is_vbrk-vbeln.
    ENDIF.
  ENDMETHOD.

Create the function module Z_REJECT_PBD_STATUS:

  • Make it RFC-enabled (to be called via tRFC)
FUNCTION z_reject_pbd_status

  " This updates VBRK-PBD_STATUS = REJECTED

    EXPORTING iv_posting                    = 'U'
              it_prebilling                 = VALUE #( ( vbeln = iv_vbeln ) )

entry.title: Supported revenue recognition methods in SAP S/4HANA Service (including SAP S/4HANA 2025 FPS0)
entry.content:
Co-Authored by Frank Hennrich and Volkmar Zahn

To help you stay compliant with accounting standards while reflecting how services are delivered and billed, SAP S/4HANA Service supports multiple revenue recognition methods across different service document types. Below is a consolidated overview of what is supported today, including innovations delivered with SAP S/4HANA 2025 FPS0.

Quick primer on methods

  • Method 15 – Completed Contract: Defer costs and revenues until an order item is fully delivered and billed; then recognize all at completion during period-end in Event-Based Revenue Recognition (EBRR).
  • Method 7 - Revenue-Based POC: Recognize revenue by progress measured via revenue (e.g., billed or simulated) relative to planned revenue.
  • Method 4 - DIP-based invoice simulation (itemized billing): For advanced execution itemized billing, a Dynamic Item Processor (DIP) simulates the invoice value of confirmed costs; EBRR uses that simulated value for revenue recognition.
  • Method 22 – Confirmation-Based: Recognize revenue based on posted service confirmations using a price simulation for the confirmations to date during period-end closing.
  • Method 3 – Cost-Based Percentage of Completion (POC): Recognize revenue by progress measured via costs incurred versus planned costs on the order/item; requires planned cost and planned revenue data.
  • Method 10 – Time-Based: Recognize revenue over time (e.g., straight-line via billing plan periods).

 Service order items (non–advanced execution)

  • Fixed-price service items (billed on completion or via billing plan)
    • Supported: Method 15 (Completed Contract), Method 3 (Cost-Based POC)
    • Not applicable: Method 22 (Confirmation-Based)
    • Notes: Planned revenue and planned costs are available, enabling POC.
  • Actuals-based items billed by consumption/confirmation (service items, expense items, part items)
    • Supported: Method 15 (Completed Contract), Method 22 (Confirmation-Based)
    • Not supported: POC methods (cost- or revenue-based)
  • Sales items (delivered via SD logistics, not via service confirmation)
    • Supported: Method 15 (Completed Contract)
  • Tool items (introduced with 2025 FPS0)
    • Supported: Method 15 (Completed Contract), Method 22 (Confirmation-Based)
    • Not supported: Fixed-price variant, Cost-Based POC
  • Service hierarchy with collective accounting
    • Supported: Method 15 (Completed Contract), Cost-Based POC
    • Note: EBRR runs on the main (parent) item only, not on sub-items.

Service with advanced execution (execution order items)

Billing relevance is the key driver for which revenue recognition options are available.

  • Itemized billing
    • Supported:
      • Method 4: DIP-based invoice simulation for revenue recognition on posted costs/confirmations
      • Method 3: Cost-Based POC (new with SAP S/4HANA 2025 FPS0). Note: Planned revenue and planned costs are available
    • Not available: Revenue-Based POC
  • Fixed-price execution order items (billed on completion or via billing plan)
    • Supported: Method 15 (Completed Contract), Method 3 (Cost-Based POC), Method 7 (Revenue-Based POC; new with SAP S/4HANA 2025 FPS0)
  • Not billing-relevant execution order items (pricing controlled by sub-price items)
    • Supported: Method 15 (Completed Contract), Method 3 (Cost-Based POC; new with SAP S/4HANA 2025 FPS0), Method 7 (Revenue-Based POC; new with SAP S/4HANA 2025 FPS0)

Service contracts

  • Classic service contract items (with billing plan or ad hoc billing)
  • Supported: Method 10 (Time-Based revenue recognition over the contract term)
  • Financial hierarchy service contract items (contract item as root of a financial hierarchy)
  • Supported: Cost-Based POC (costs can be assigned to the contract item, enabling POC)
  • Note: Enables POC-style recognition on the contract root item. The concept of using service contract items as the root item of a financial hierarchy was introduced in SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS2. This functionality is available only when item-based accounting is activated for service management. In this scenario, service order items assigned to the contract item do not receive individual account assignments and cannot be assigned separate revenue recognition keys. Instead, all assigned service order items contribute to financial reporting at the contract item level. This enables comprehensive support for revenue recognition, margin analysis, and other reporting capabilities—aggregated at the contract item level. Currently, the only supported revenue recognition method for contract items used as the root of a financial hierarchy is cost-based percentage of completion (POC), also known as Method 3. Depending on the configuration of the associated virtual plan category, the system supports:
    • Automated revenue and cost planning
    • Manual revenue and cost planning
    • Hybrid approaches combining both automated and manual planning

More information on how the financial hierarchy service contract items are supported in Event-Based Revenue Recognition and which service order item types can be assigned to it is provided in Event-Based Revenue Recognition for Service Contracts as Root Items in Financial Hierarchy | SAP Help.

What’s new with SAP S/4HANA 2025 FPS0

  • Support of cost-based POC revenue recognition for execution order items with itemized billing
  • Tool items as a service document type, with support for Completed Contract and Confirmation-Based recognition (no fixed-price variant and no POC for tool items)
  • Support of the “revenue-based percentage of completion” method for fixed-price services with advanced execution
  • Support for cost-based percentage of completion for service contracts with service order items (non-advanced execution) and with execution order items of billing relevance itemized billing or billing via billing plan
  • Consistent settlement of hierarchies, including settlement to cost-based CO-PA

Choosing the right method

  • Use Completed Contract (Method 15) when you recognize only after full delivery and billing
  • Use Confirmation-Based (Method 22) for actuals-based service scenarios where confirmations drive billing and recognition
  • Use Cost-Based POC (Method 3) when you can reliably plan costs and revenue and want to recognize by progress
  • Use Revenue-Based POC when revenue milestones or billings best represent progress
  • Use Time-Based (Method 10) for classic service contracts recognized over time via a billing plan

For a more detailed information on how the revenue methods work you can refer to Revenue Recognition Methods for Service Order Items | SAP Help and Revenue Recognition Methods for Execution Order Items | SAP Help.

Implementation notes

  • Availability can depend on item category, billing relevance, and whether planned data exists. Ensure that item configuration and planning data align with the chosen method.
  • For itemized billing in advanced execution, confirm DIP configuration so invoice simulation values are available to EBRR.
  • For hierarchies, remember recognition runs on the main item (service hierarchy with collective accounting) or the contract root (financial hierarchy contract items), not on all sub-items.

This overview is intended to help you align service scenarios with the appropriate revenue recognition method in SAP S/4HANA Service. For detailed setup steps and prerequisites, consult the SAP Help Portal and application documentation corresponding to your release.

SAP S/4HANA Service offers a robust framework for revenue recognition across a variety of service scenarios. With the 2025 FPS0 release, the platform continues to expand its capabilities, especially in advanced execution and financial hierarchies. These enhancements empower organizations to align their service operations with financial compliance requirements more effectively.

If you're planning to implement or optimize revenue recognition in your SAP S/4HANA landscape, understanding these supported methods is a crucial step. For more details or guidance, feel free to engage with the SAP community or reach out to your SAP representative.

entry.title: Adaptation Project: SAP標準Fioriアプリのフィルタ項目を必須入力へするための方法
entry.content:
1. はじめに

SAP標準Fioriアプリは、S/4HANAを利用した業務プロセスを支援する重要なツールとして活用されており、Fiori Elementsフレームワークの実装技術を用いたアプリが多く提供されています。しかし、企業固有の業務要件や特定のユーザーのニーズに完全に対応するためには、標準アプリをカスタマイズする必要が生じることがあります。
Fioriアプリのカスタマイズには、メタデータ拡張やUI適応などいくつかの手法が提供されています。しかし、拡張対象オブジェクトがメタデータ拡張に対応していない場合やUI適応による変更では対応できない業務要件が発生する場合があります。そのような場合に、より柔軟なUI拡張手法として利用可能な方法が、Adaptation Project（Developer Adaptation）です。Adaptation Projectを使用することで、標準のSAP Fiori elementsアプリケーションをモディフィケーションフリーで拡張することが可能になります。つまり、元のアプリケーションを変更することなく、新しいアプリケーションバリアントを作成し、独自の要件に合わせてカスタマイズが可能となります。

本ブログでは、SAP標準Fioriアプリ（F0842A: Manage Purchase Orders）に定義されたフィルタ項目（プラント）を必須化する要件を対象に、SAP Business Application Studioを使用してAdaptation Projectを作成し、Local Annotationを追加して標準アプリのカスタマイズを実現する具体的な手順について詳しく解説していきます。

 

2. 実装方法

1. SAP Business Application Studioへアクセスし、SAP FioriのDev spaceを開きます。

 

2. Open FolderからProjectsフォルダ（/home/user/projects/）へアクセスします。

 

 

 

3. File>New Project from Templateを開き、SAPUI5 Adaptation Projectを選択します。

 

 

 

4.System and Application Selectionで以下を入力後、Nextをクリックして設定を進めます。

System：拡張対象アプリのS/4HANAへのDestination
Application：拡張対象アプリ（本ブログでは、Manage Purchase Orders）

 

5. Project Attributesに以下の情報を入力します。

Project Name：任意のプロジェクト名称
Application Title：任意のアプリタイトル
Namespace：入力したプロジェクト名称をもとに自動生成されます（必要に応じて、変更可能です）。
Project Folder Path：Projectsフォルダへのパスが自動入力されます（必要に応じて、変更可能です）。
SAPUI5 Version：最新のSAPUI5バージョンが自動入力されます（ここでは、変更できません。S/4HANAへインストールされたSAPUI5バージョンへ変更する場合は、プロジェクト生成後にui5.yamlファイルの変更が必要になります。詳細は、SAP KBA：3095848 - How to change SAPUI5 version if problems occur for Adaptation Project in BAS をご確認ください）。
Add Deployment Configuration：Yes（デプロイ設定のため）

 

6. Deployment Configurationに以下の情報を入力後、Finishボタンをクリックしてプロジェクトを生成します。

Destination：System and Application Selectionで選択したDestinationが自動入力されます（必要に応じて変更可能です）。
Select How You Want to Enter the Package：デプロイ用パッケージの選択方法をEnter Manually / Choose from Existingのいずれかを選択します。
Package：デプロイ用パッケージを選択します（スクリーンショットは、例としてローカルパッケージを設定しています）。

 

 

 

7. 生成されたプロジェクトを右クリックして、Add Local Annotation Fileからアノテーションファイルを生成します（Application InformationのAdd Local Annotation Fileボタンからも可能です）。

 

 

 

8. Add Local Annotation Fileで以下の情報を入力します。

Target OData Service: mainService（自動入力されます。）
Annotation XML: Create local annotation file from template（新規作成する場合）/ Select annotation file from workspace（既存のアノテーションファイルを参照する場合）

 

 

9. プロジェクトフォルダのwebapp/changes/annotations配下にアノテーションファイルが新規作成されるため、開きます。

 

 

10. アノテーションファイルに以下のアノテーション実装を追加します（実装内容詳細は、次のセクションで解説します）。

<edmx:Edmx xmlns:edmx="http://docs.oasis-open.org/odata/ns/edmx" Version="4.0">
    <edmx:Reference Uri="https://sap.github.io/odata-vocabularies/vocabularies/Common.xml">
        <edmx:Include Namespace="com.sap.vocabularies.Common.v1" Alias="Common"/>
    </edmx:Reference>
    <edmx:Reference Uri="https://sap.github.io/odata-vocabularies/vocabularies/UI.xml">
        <edmx:Include Namespace="com.sap.vocabularies.UI.v1" Alias="UI"/>
    </edmx:Reference>
    <edmx:Reference Uri="https://sap.github.io/odata-vocabularies/vocabularies/Communication.xml">
        <edmx:Include Namespace="com.sap.vocabularies.Communication.v1" Alias="Communication"/>
    </edmx:Reference>
    <edmx:Reference Uri="/sap/opu/odata/sap/MM_PUR_PO_MAINT_V2_SRV/$metadata">
        <edmx:Include Namespace="MM_PUR_PO_MAINT_V2_SRV"/>
    </edmx:Reference>
    <edmx:Reference Uri="/sap/opu/odata/iwfnd/catalogservice;v=2/Vocabularies(TechnicalName='%2FIWBEP%2FVOC_CAPABILITIES',Version='0001',SAP__Origin='')/$value">
          <edmx:Include Namespace="Org.OData.Capabilities.V1" Alias="Capabilities"/>
    </edmx:Reference>
    <edmx:DataServices>
        <Schema xmlns="http://docs.oasis-open.org/odata/ns/edm" Namespace="local_1760320506713">
            <Annotations Target="MM_PUR_PO_MAINT_V2_SRV.MM_PUR_PO_MAINT_V2_SRV_Entities/C_PurchaseOrderTP"> 
                <Annotation Term="Capabilities.FilterRestrictions"> 
                    <Record> 
                        <PropertyValue Property="RequiresFilter" Bool="true"/> 
                        <PropertyValue Property="RequiredProperties"> 
                            <Collection> 
                                <PropertyPath>Plant</PropertyPath> 
                            </Collection> 
                        </PropertyValue> 
                    </Record> 
                </Annotation> 
            </Annotations>
        </Schema>
    </edmx:DataServices>
</edmx:Edmx>

 

 

 

11. manifest.appdescr_variantファイルにアプリが追加アノテーションを参照するための定義を追加します。

 

 

{
  "fileName": "manifest",
  "layer": "CUSTOMER_BASE",
  "fileType": "appdescr_variant",
  "reference": "ui.ssuite.s2p.mm.pur.po.manage.st.s1",
  "id": "customer.zapp.f0842a",
  "namespace": "apps/ui.ssuite.s2p.mm.pur.po.manage.st.s1/appVariants/customer.zapp.f0842a/",
  "version": "0.1.0",
  "content": [
    {
      "changeType": "appdescr_ui5_addNewModelEnhanceWith",
      "content": {
        "modelId": "i18n"
      },
      "texts": {
        "i18n": "i18n/i18n.properties"
      }
    },
    {
      "changeType": "appdescr_ui5_addNewModelEnhanceWith",
      "content": {
        "modelId": "@i18n"
      },
      "texts": {
        "i18n": "i18n/i18n.properties"
      }
    },
    {
      "changeType": "appdescr_ui5_addNewModelEnhanceWith",
      "content": {
        "modelId": "i18n|sap.suite.ui.generic.template.ListReport|C_PurchaseOrderTP"
      },
      "texts": {
        "i18n": "i18n/ListReport/C_PurchaseOrderTP/i18n.properties"
      }
    },
    {
      "changeType": "appdescr_ui5_addNewModelEnhanceWith",
      "content": {
        "modelId": "i18n|sap.suite.ui.generic.template.ObjectPage|C_PurchaseOrderTP"
      },
      "texts": {
        "i18n": "i18n/ObjectPage/C_PurchaseOrderTP/i18n.properties"
      }
    },
    {
      "changeType": "appdescr_ui5_addNewModelEnhanceWith",
      "content": {
        "modelId": "i18n|sap.suite.ui.generic.template.ObjectPage|C_PurchaseOrderItemTP"
      },
      "texts": {
        "i18n": "i18n/ObjectPage/C_PurchaseOrderItemTP/i18n.properties"
      }
    },
    {
      "changeType": "appdescr_ui5_addNewModelEnhanceWith",
      "content": {
        "modelId": "i18n|sap.suite.ui.generic.template.ObjectPage|C_PurchaseOrderLimitItemTP"
      },
      "texts": {
        "i18n": "i18n/ObjectPage/C_PurchaseOrderLimitItemTP/i18n.properties"
      }
    },
    {
      "changeType": "appdescr_ui5_setMinUI5Version",
      "content": {
        "minUI5Version": "1.114.9"
      }
    },
    {
      "changeType": "appdescr_app_setTitle",
      "content": {},
      "texts": {
        "i18n": "i18n/i18n.properties"
      }
    },
    { 
      "changeType": "appdescr_app_addAnnotationsToOData", 
      "content": { 
        "dataSourceId": "mainService", 
        "annotations": [ "customer.myAnno" ], 
        "annotationsInsertPosition": "END", 
        "dataSource": { 
          "customer.myAnno": { 
            "uri": "changes/annotations/annotation_1760320506713.xml", 
            "type": "ODataAnnotation" 
          } 
        } 
      } 
    }
  ]
}

 

 

 

12. webappを右クリック>Preview Applicationからアプリをプレビュー実行します（Application InformationのPreview Applicationボタンからも可能です）。

 

 

13. プラント項目が必須入力項目となっていることを確認します。

 

 

14. webappを右クリック>Deploy Applicationからアプリをデプロイします（Application InformationのDeployボタンからも可能です）。

 

 

 

15. デプロイしたアプリ（アプリバリアント）は、Fiori技術カタログにSemantic object / semantic action / SAPUI5 Component / タイル等を定義し、ビジネスカタログおよびビジネスロールから参照することでエンドユーザからの利用が可能となります。

Semantic Object: 任意のセマンティックオブジェクト
Action: 任意のセマンティックアクション
SAPUI5 Component ID: Step.5でのプロジェクト生成時のNamespace

 

3. 実装内容解説

1. Local Annotationファイル（annotation_xxx.xml）

ローカルアノテーションファイルは、標準Fioriアプリで使用されているODataサービスにアノテーションによる拡張を実装したファイルです。ファイル内の記述は、ODataの構文に準じた記述になり、以下のような制約があります（一部抜粋）。

  • edmx:Edmx
    • ルート要素であり、<edmx:Edmx> ～ </edmx:Edmx>の間に、構文を記述します。<edmx:Edmx>の定義には Version の記述と <edmx:DataServices>エレメントが 1 つ含まれている必要があります。
  • edmx:Reference
    • アノテーションファイル内で参照される外部 CSDL(Common Schema Definition Language) 文書を指定します。子エレメント edmx:Referenceには、 Uri（参照先のURI）の記述と最低1つのedmx:Include エレメントが含まれている必要があります。
  • edmx:Include
    • 参照される CSDL ドキュメント配下のスキーマを指定します。Namespace（スキーマ名称）を指定する必要があります。また、Aliasを指定することもできます。
  • edmx:Dataservices
    • Annotaionのプロパティ等を記述する要素で、1 つの Schemaエレメントが含まれている必要があります。Schemaエレメント内にアノテーションを記述します。
  • Annotations
    • 拡張するODataサービスのEntitySet名を含むターゲット属性を指定します。最低1つのAnnotation エレメントが含まれている必要があります。

これらの構文に従って、プラントのフィルタ項目を入力必須化にする実装をしています。

  • 拡張対象ターゲットの特定
    本ブログの実装では、以下のTarget情報が必要となります。
  1. Target：MM_PUR_PO_MAINT_V2_SRV.MM_PUR_PO_MAINT_V2_SRV_Entities/C_PurchaseOrderTP
    • OData Service Name: MM_PUR_PO_MAINT_V2_SRV
    • EntityContainer Name: MM_PUR_PO_MAINT_V2_SRV_Entities
    • EntitySet Name: C_PurchaseOrderTP (*Not EntityType Name)
  2. PropertyPath：Plant
  3. OData サービス名: SAP Fiori Apps Reference Library（https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/#) から、拡張対象のFioriアプリを検索します。対象アプリのページの“IMPLEMENTATION INFORMATION” タブの“Configuration”の中のOData ServiceにFioriアプリで使用されているODataが記載されています。

4. EntityContainer名
対象のODataサービスのメタデータを確認します（https://<IP Adress>:<Port Number>/sap/opu/odata/sap/ MM_PUR_PO_MAINT_V2_SRV/$metadata）。
EntityContainerと検索すると、EntityContainer名を確認できます。

 

5. EntitySet 名
Fioriアプリ “購買発注管理” の起動時に、ブラウザの開発者ツールでmanifest.appdescrに対するリクエストのPreview / Responseを確認すると、List Reportに使用されるエンティティセットは、“C_PurchaseOrderTP”であることがわかります。

6. PropertyPath
対象のODataサービスのメタデータの対象エンティティセットの定義を確認することで項目名（PropertyPath）を特定することが可能です。

 

  • 拡張対象およびアノテーションによる変更プロパティの設定
    1. “購買発注管理” に使用されているODataサービス“MM_PUR_PO_MAINT_V2_SRV”のメタデータをロードして、アノテーションによる拡張対象の項目を持つCDS ViewをTargetに設定しています。
    2. 実装では、FilterRestrictionsを使用してプロパティ"RequiresFilter"と"RequiredProperties"を変更することが目的のため、FilterRestrictionsを含む"Org.OData.Capabilities.V1" vocabularyを指定したエイリアスで参照しています。

 

2. manifest.appdescr_variant.json

manifest.appdescr_variant.jsonは、元のアプリで利用可能なオブジェクトを記述したファイルで、多くの設定は標準アプリのmanifest情報を参照しています。ローカルアノテーションファイルを追加する場合は、以下のプロパティを設定します。

"dataSourceId" ：対象のODataサービスを指定するプロパティで本シナリオでは"mainService" です。
"annotations"：指定したODataデータソース"mainService"に対して、でアノテーションの名前を指定します。名称は "customer" で始まる必要があります (例: "customer.myAnno")。
"annotationsInsertPosition" ："END" に設定する必要があります。そうでない場合、これらはサーバのユーザによって無効化され、まったく効果がない可能性があります。
"dataSource"："customer" で始まるアノテーション名を指定します。"uri"で作成したローカルアノテーションファイルを指定し、"type"をODataへのアノテーション追加の場合は、"ODataAnnotation"とします。

 

4. まとめ

本記事では、SAP Business Application StudioでAdaptation Projectを作成し、Local Annotationを追加してフィルタ項目を必須化する手順について紹介しました。Adaptation Projectでは、フィルタの必須化以外にもアノテーション実装の変更やコントローラ拡張やカスタムXMLフラグメントの追加などの拡張が可能です。Adaptation Projectの詳細については、参考情報に記載のドキュメントをご確認ください。

 

参考情報

SAP Help: Extending an SAP Fiori Application for an SAP S/4HANA or SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition
SAP Blog: Extending SAP-delivered SAP Fiori elements apps using adaptation projects to create SAP S/4HANA app variants
SAP KBA: https://me.sap.com/notes/3285957

entry.title: Segment '_records' not allowed in the current context
entry.content:
Hello experts,

In my effort to learn ABAP RAP I'm trying to created simple Job Application Management app which maintains information about applications from the point of view of the applicant. To its root cds view ZI_APPLICATION are associated contact person data (ZI_PERSON), company data (ZI_COMPANY) and composed ZI_RECORDS (as _records) to maintain some records (e.g. date of interview, its result etc.)

When I try to create new record to an application, I get "Segment '_records' not allowed in the current context" error, yet I am able to create the record. Can anybody explain me how to rid of this error?

I inspected the ZFE_TRAVEL_001000 example present on the server which has sort of similar structure (associations and composition) but even if I created as similar structure (cds, annotations, classes etc.) as possible I still cannot make it work. entry.title: Incorrect Invoice Header Data Copied from Another Document During Collective Billing VF04
entry.content:
Description:

We are encountering an issue in SAP S/4HANA during collective billing (transaction VF04) where the invoice header data (table VBRK) appears to be incorrect for certain invoices.

Specifically:

The VBRK-NETWR (invoice header net value) does not match the sum of the item-level net values (VBRP-NETWR).

The header fields, such as VBRK-KUNAG (sold-to party) and VBRK-KUNRG (payer), seem to have been copied from another invoice processed in the same collective billing run.

This issue also results in the accounting document being posted to the wrong customer, since the customer data in VBRK is incorrect.

Has anyone experienced a similar issue during collective billing via VF04?

Could this be due to a data inconsistency, incorrect buffering, or possibly a custom routine/BADI or user exit involved in the billing creation process?

Any insights or recommendations for identifying the root cause would be appreciated.

entry.title: Building the Future of Enterprise AI: MCP Servers and Agent-to-Agent Communication Revolution
entry.content:
Building the Future of Enterprise AI: MCP Servers and Agent-to-Agent Communication Revolution

Transforming how AI systems collaborate in modern enterprise environments

 

The enterprise AI landscape is experiencing a paradigm shift. While individual AI agents have proven their worth in specific domains, the real transformation happens when these intelligent systems can seamlessly collaborate, share knowledge, and coordinate complex workflows. Enter two revolutionary protocols that are reshaping how we think about AI integration: Model Context Protocol (MCP) and Agent-to-Agent Protocol (A2A).

The Integration Challenge: Breaking Down AI Silos

Picture this: You're managing an e-commerce platform with specialized AI agents for inventory management, fraud detection, customer recommendations, and order fulfillment. Each agent performs exceptionally within its domain, but when a customer wants to modify a large order that was flagged for unusual purchasing patterns while using a promotional code—suddenly your streamlined system becomes a coordination nightmare.

This scenario illustrates the fundamental challenge facing modern enterprises: AI agents operating in isolation. Without standardized communication protocols, organizations struggle with:

  • Integration Complexity: Each new AI tool requires custom integration work, consuming valuable development resources
  • Data Inconsistency: Different systems use varying data formats, leading to translation errors and processing delays
  • Workflow Fragmentation: Multi-step processes require manual intervention to bridge gaps between AI systems
  • Scalability Limitations: Adding new capabilities means exponentially more integration points to maintain

The result? Expensive, brittle AI implementations that fail to deliver their full potential.

Model Context Protocol (MCP): The Universal AI Language

 

Model Context Protocol addresses the first half of this challenge by creating a standardized way for AI applications to communicate with external systems and data sources. Developed by Anthropic, MCP serves as a universal translator that eliminates the need for custom integrations.

How MCP Transforms System Integration

Traditional AI integration requires developers to:

  • Learn each system's unique API structure
  • Handle different authentication methods
  • Parse varying data formats
  • Maintain separate codebases for each integration

MCP changes this by providing a unified interface that abstracts away system-specific complexities. Think of it as having a universal remote control that works with every device in your smart home, regardless of brand or model.

Core MCP Components

MCP Host: Acts as the central coordination hub, managing all communication between AI clients and external systems.

MCP Client: Represents your AI application that needs to access external resources or capabilities.

MCP Server: Exposes specific functionalities, data sources, or services in a standardized format that any MCP client can understand.

What MCP Servers Provide

Tools: Executable functions that AI agents can discover and use dynamically. For example, a customer service AI could discover and invoke tools for order lookup, refund processing, or inventory checking without needing pre-programmed knowledge of each system.

Resources: Access to both static and dynamic data sources. This might include real-time inventory levels, customer databases, product catalogs, or analytical reports—all accessible through a consistent interface.

Prompts: Reusable, parameterized templates that maintain consistency across different AI interactions while allowing for customization based on specific contexts.

Real-World MCP Benefits: E-commerce Transformation

Consider an online retailer implementing MCP across their AI ecosystem:

Before MCP: Their recommendation engine needed separate integrations with the inventory system, customer database, pricing engine, and analytics platform. Each integration required months of development and ongoing maintenance.

After MCP: The recommendation engine simply queries the MCP ecosystem for "customer profile," "available products," and "pricing data." The MCP servers handle all the complexity of connecting to underlying systems, transforming data formats, and managing authentication.

Result: Development time reduced from months to weeks, maintenance overhead decreased by 60%, and new AI capabilities can be added without touching existing integrations.

MCP's Business Impact

Accelerated Development: Teams can focus on AI logic rather than integration plumbing, reducing time-to-market for new AI features by up to 70%.

Enhanced Reliability: Standardized interfaces reduce integration bugs and improve system stability.

Future-Proofing: When underlying systems change, only the MCP server needs updating—all connected AI clients continue working without modification.

Cost Efficiency: Reduced integration complexity means lower development and maintenance costs, with some organizations reporting 50% savings on AI infrastructure expenses.

Agent-to-Agent Protocol (A2A): Orchestrating AI Collaboration

 

While MCP solves the AI-to-system challenge, Agent-to-Agent Protocol tackles the equally important problem of AI-to-AI communication. A2A enables different AI agents to discover, communicate, and coordinate with each other to handle complex, multi-step workflows.

The Multi-Agent Coordination Challenge

Modern business processes rarely fit within a single AI agent's capabilities. Consider a customer support scenario where a client reports a billing error on their account. This seemingly simple request actually requires coordination between:

  • Customer Service AI: To understand the query and manage the interaction
  • Billing System AI: To identify and analyze the billing discrepancy
  • Fraud Detection AI: To ensure the request isn't part of a fraudulent pattern
  • Account Management AI: To determine appropriate remediation steps

Without A2A, each handoff between agents requires manual intervention or custom integration work.

A2A's Coordination Framework

Dynamic Discovery: Agents can automatically discover other agents' capabilities through standardized "Agent Cards" that describe what each agent can do, what inputs it needs, and what outputs it provides.

Role-Based Organization: A2A defines clear roles—coordinators who manage workflows, specialists who handle specific tasks, and observers who monitor and provide insights.

Task Lifecycle Management: Every interaction follows a structured lifecycle from task creation through completion, with standardized status updates and error handling.

Flexible Communication: Agents can exchange various content types—text, images, structured data, or complex multimedia—through a unified messaging framework.

Transformative Healthcare Use Case

Let's explore how A2A revolutionizes healthcare coordination—a domain where precise, timely collaboration literally saves lives:

Scenario: A patient arrives at the emergency department with chest pain.

Traditional Approach:

  • Triage nurse manually enters patient data into multiple systems
  • Various specialists are paged individually
  • Lab orders are placed through separate systems
  • Results are manually communicated between departments
  • Treatment decisions involve multiple phone calls and consultations

A2A-Enabled Approach: The Emergency Coordinator Agent automatically orchestrates the entire process:

  1. Immediate Assessment: Delegates initial evaluation to the Triage AI, which processes symptoms and assigns priority
  2. Parallel Specialist Coordination: Simultaneously engages Cardiology AI for cardiac risk assessment, Lab AI for stat blood work orders, and Radiology AI for imaging protocols
  3. Real-Time Collaboration: As results become available, each specialist AI provides recommendations that are automatically integrated into a comprehensive assessment
  4. Coordinated Decision Making: The Treatment Planning AI synthesizes all inputs to recommend optimal care pathways
  5. Resource Optimization: Bed Management AI ensures appropriate room assignment while Pharmacy AI prepares necessary medications

Outcome: What traditionally took hours of coordination happens in minutes, with improved accuracy and reduced human error.

A2A's Healthcare Benefits

Reduced Response Times: Emergency protocols that previously required 30-45 minutes now complete in under 10 minutes.

Improved Accuracy: Standardized communication eliminates transcription errors and ensures all relevant information is considered.

Enhanced Care Quality: Parallel processing allows for more comprehensive evaluation without delays.

Resource Optimization: Intelligent coordination prevents resource conflicts and optimizes staff utilization.

Audit Trail: Every decision and communication is logged, providing complete visibility into care processes.

The Synergy: MCP + A2A = Enterprise AI Excellence

The true power emerges when MCP and A2A work together, creating an ecosystem where AI agents can seamlessly access any enterprise system while coordinating sophisticated workflows with other agents.

Manufacturing Excellence Example

Consider a smart manufacturing facility where quality control, predictive maintenance, supply chain, and production planning agents work together:

MCP Integration: Each agent accesses manufacturing data through standardized interfaces—production metrics, equipment sensors, inventory levels, and quality reports—without needing to understand the underlying industrial systems.

A2A Coordination: When the predictive maintenance agent detects potential equipment failure, it automatically:

  • Alerts the production planning agent to adjust schedules
  • Informs the supply chain agent to expedite replacement parts
  • Notifies the quality control agent to increase inspection frequency
  • Coordinates with the facility management agent to schedule maintenance windows

Result: Unplanned downtime reduced by 80%, maintenance costs decreased by 40%, and product quality improved through proactive interventions.

Financial Services Transformation

In banking, compliance, risk management, customer service, and fraud detection agents collaborate to provide comprehensive financial services:

Real-Time Risk Assessment: When a customer applies for a loan, the application automatically triggers parallel processing across multiple AI agents—credit analysis, fraud detection, regulatory compliance, and market risk assessment—with results synthesized in minutes rather than days.

Automated Compliance: Regulatory changes automatically propagate through the agent network, with each agent updating its decision-making criteria and reporting mechanisms without human intervention.

Enhanced Customer Experience: Customer service agents can instantly access comprehensive customer profiles while coordinating with specialized agents for investment advice, loan modifications, or dispute resolution.

Strategic Implementation Benefits

Organizational Advantages

Scalability Without Complexity: Adding new AI capabilities becomes as simple as plugging in new agents—the underlying infrastructure handles all communication and coordination automatically.

Reduced Technical Debt: Standardized protocols eliminate the accumulation of custom integrations that become expensive to maintain over time.

Faster Innovation: Teams can experiment with new AI agents without worrying about integration challenges, accelerating the pace of innovation.

Improved ROI: Organizations typically see 3x faster deployment of new AI capabilities and 60% reduction in integration costs.

Operational Excellence

Enhanced Reliability: Built-in error handling, circuit breakers, and failover mechanisms ensure system resilience even when individual components fail.

Better Visibility: Comprehensive monitoring and logging provide unprecedented insight into AI system performance and decision-making processes.

Simplified Management: Centralized configuration and monitoring reduce operational complexity while improving control over AI behaviors.

Compliance Readiness: Standardized audit trails and governance frameworks make it easier to meet regulatory requirements.

Addressing Implementation Challenges

Security and Trust Considerations

Authentication and Authorization: Both protocols include robust security frameworks to ensure only authorized agents can access specific resources or communicate with other agents.

Data Privacy: Built-in privacy controls protect sensitive information while enabling necessary collaboration between agents.

Audit and Compliance: Comprehensive logging and monitoring capabilities support regulatory requirements and internal governance policies.

Performance Optimization

Efficient Communication: Both protocols are designed for high-performance scenarios with minimal overhead and optimized message formats.

Load Balancing: Intelligent distribution of work across agent networks prevents bottlenecks and ensures optimal resource utilization.

Caching and Optimization: Smart caching mechanisms reduce redundant operations and improve overall system responsiveness.

Change Management

Gradual Adoption: Organizations can implement MCP and A2A incrementally, starting with high-value use cases and expanding over time.

Training and Education: Success requires investment in team education to help developers and administrators understand the new paradigms.

Cultural Shift: Moving from custom integrations to standardized protocols requires organizational commitment to new development approaches.

Future Outlook: The Evolution of AI Collaboration

Emerging Trends

Multi-Modal Communication: Next-generation implementations will support rich media communications, enabling agents to share images, video, audio, and complex data visualizations as part of their coordination efforts.

Federated Learning: Agents will be able to share and improve their models collaboratively while maintaining data privacy and security.

Self-Healing Networks: Advanced implementations will automatically detect and recover from failures, redistributing work and spawning replacement agents as needed.

Cross-Organization Collaboration: Future versions may enable secure collaboration between agents across organizational boundaries, creating industry-wide AI ecosystems.

Industry-Specific Evolution

Healthcare: Integration with medical devices, electronic health records, and regulatory systems will enable comprehensive patient care coordination.

Financial Services: Real-time market data integration and regulatory compliance automation will transform trading, lending, and risk management.

Manufacturing: Integration with IoT sensors, robotics, and supply chain systems will enable fully autonomous production optimization.

Retail: Seamless integration across online and offline channels will create truly omnichannel customer experiences.

Measuring Success: Key Performance Indicators

Technical Metrics

Integration Speed: Time to integrate new AI capabilities reduced from months to weeks

System Reliability: Uptime improvements of 99.9% or higher through robust error handling

Performance Optimization: Response time improvements of 40-60% through efficient communication protocols

Maintenance Reduction: 50-70% reduction in integration maintenance overhead

Business Metrics

Time to Market: Accelerated deployment of new AI features and capabilities

Cost Savings: Reduced development and maintenance costs through standardization

Innovation Velocity: Increased rate of AI experimentation and deployment

Competitive Advantage: Enhanced ability to respond quickly to market changes and opportunities

Getting Started: Practical Implementation Steps

Phase 1: Assessment and Planning

Current State Analysis: Evaluate existing AI implementations and identify integration pain points

Use Case Prioritization: Select high-value scenarios where MCP and A2A can deliver immediate benefits

Technical Readiness: Assess infrastructure and team capabilities for protocol implementation

Phase 2: Pilot Implementation

Limited Scope Deployment: Start with a single, well-defined use case to prove value and learn lessons

Performance Baseline: Establish metrics for comparing before and after implementation results

Team Training: Invest in education and skill development for development and operations teams

Phase 3: Scaled Deployment

Gradual Expansion: Systematically extend implementation to additional use cases and systems

Governance Framework: Establish policies and procedures for managing the expanded AI ecosystem

Continuous Optimization: Regular performance review and optimization of agent interactions and system performance

Conclusion: The Collaborative AI Future

The integration of Model Context Protocol and Agent-to-Agent Protocol represents a fundamental shift in how we architect and deploy enterprise AI systems. By standardizing communication between AI and enterprise systems (MCP) and enabling sophisticated coordination between AI agents (A2A), organizations can unlock the full potential of collaborative artificial intelligence.

The transformation is profound:

  • Development cycles shortened from months to weeks
  • Maintenance overhead reduced by 50-70%
  • System reliability improved to 99.9%+ uptime
  • Innovation velocity increased by 3x or more

The opportunity is immediate:

  • Protocols are mature and ready for enterprise deployment
  • Implementation can begin with high-value, low-risk pilot projects
  • Benefits compound as more agents and systems join the ecosystem

The competitive advantage is significant:

  • Organizations that adopt these protocols will be able to deploy AI capabilities faster and more reliably than competitors
  • The ability to coordinate complex, multi-agent workflows will become a key differentiator
  • Standardized approaches will enable innovation at unprecedented scale

Whether you're in healthcare, finance, manufacturing, or retail, MCP and A2A provide the foundation for building sophisticated, resilient, and scalable AI ecosystems that can transform how your organization operates and competes.

The future of enterprise AI isn't about individual agents working in isolation—it's about orchestrated networks of specialized agents working together seamlessly to deliver exceptional business outcomes. Start your journey toward collaborative AI excellence today.

Key Resources:

  • Technical Implementation: Consider partnering with experienced system integrators who understand both protocols

entry.title: What’s New in Subscription Order Management 2025 FPS00
entry.content:
New Release

PUBLIC

  October 2025

We’re thrilled to announce that, effective October 8th, 2025, the Subscription Order Management (SOM) 2025 FPS00 release is now generally available for our customers.

This release brings a comprehensive suite of new advanced functionalities, enhancements in mass processing applications, improved user experience, along with an expanded integration capability designed to empower your business in a rapidly evolving subscription economy.

Let's dive into these latest product features in detail.

Subscription with Recurring Delivery of Physical Products

Imagine Elite Printing Solutions, a growing printer company that offers a Printer-as-a-Service model to its customers. Under this subscription model, the company provides high-end printers bundled with a recurring supply of toner cartridges, standard printing paper, and other essentials, all delivered directly to the customer’s premises or offices. Customers prefer such subscription-based models as they eliminate operational overhead and remove the need for upfront investment or ownership of premium-priced printers.

Traditionally, it has been challenging to manage such hybrid subscription scenarios, where physical devices and consumables are delivered at regular intervals. Businesses have often had to manually trigger and track deliveries and ensure accurate billing. Moreover, handling adjustments, such as adding new flavors or increasing ordered quantities to match the growing consumption, had also increased the complexity. These manual efforts frequently led to operational inefficiencies, billing errors, and missed opportunities to scale adaptive subscription models.

Figure 1: Illustration of the Coffee Subscription Use Case

 

 

Do you see similar business scenarios in your industry? Now, imagine extending this subscription-based recurring model which includes periodic delivery of physical items extending to other sectors. Imagine in fashion retail, you can receive curated boxes of clothing or accessories at regular intervals, industrial consumables having periodic replenishment of tools, safety gear, or machine parts, vending machines-as-a-service, or even medical and healthcare equipment (e.g., dialysis machines, infusion pumps) or consumables (e.g., syringes, test kits) requiring regular replenishment.

Thanks to the new Recurring Delivery Subscription feature in SOM, these challenges can now be managed seamlessly as part of the out of the box solution. You can now easily design and manage subscription models that cater to businesses across diverse industries and sectors.

Figure 2: Recurring Sales Item and Delivery Plan

Benefits:

  • Offer unified subscription experiences by bundling products, services, and recurring deliveries into a single, seamless subscription model.
  • Out of the box standard scheduling of replenishments with subscription to reduce manual effort and errors.
  • Enhance customer satisfaction with consistent, on-time delivery of essential products and services.
  • Enable flexible growth by allowing easy adjustments to delivery frequency, product mix, and subscription tiers as customer needs evolve.

Constraints:

  • In the current release, it is not possible to create a subscription order or a solution quotation with a recurring sales item using an API. It can only be done from the UI.
  • Recurring sales items are not visible in the Manage Subscription Contract Lifecycle Fiori app. That is, if you open a subscription contract with a recurring sales item in the Manage Subscription Contract Lifecycle Fiori app, the recurring sales items won't be visible in the contract hierarchy.
  • These features are on our product roadmap and are already planned for upcoming releases.

 For more information about this new feature, refer to Subscription with Recurring Delivery of Physical Products topic on the SAP Help Portal.

Target Quantity for Subscriptions in Master agreement

Have you ever faced a situation where an enterprise customer orders 100 units but requests delivery of only 30 upfront, with the rest spread out over the year? Managing such partial deliveries becomes even more complex when special pricing or discounts are configured in the master agreements. Without proper tracking, businesses often struggle to monitor how much of the committed quantity has already been delivered and how much remains, leading to billing errors, disputes, or missed revenue opportunities.

Let’s consider a scenario where, a healthcare equipment provider offers ultrasound machines on a subscription basis to hospitals. A hospital signs a multi-year subscription with a special pricing agreement in the master agreement for 10 devices. However, the hospital intends to have a phased rollout (delivery) across departments rather than taking all machines at once.

  • As part the initial deployment, the hospital plans a partial shipment of 4 ultrasound machines.
  • In the second shipment, the hospital requests 5 more machines as their expansion continues.
  • In the final shipment, the hospital installs the remaining 1 machine to complete the plan

 

 

Target quantity

Figure 3: Target quantity in Master Agreement

With the new Target Quantity feature in SAP Subscription Order Management (SOM), such scenarios are now easy to be managed out-of-the -box.

  • Businesses can define a target quantity for a subscription product directly in the master agreement.
  • Call-Off transactions (orders or solution quotations) can be created until the total released quantity reaches the defined target.
  • Each time a new call-off is created, the system automatically checks the cumulative ordered quantity against the target quantity.
  • If the new request will exceed the agreed limit, the system prevents over-ordering, ensuring compliance with the contract terms.
  • The target quantity remains flexible and editable even after the master agreement is released, allowing businesses to adjust as their needs evolve.

For more information about this new feature, refer to Creating Call Offs with Reference to Master Agreements on the SAP Help Portal.

Best Practice Content (Scope Item 7WB)
Subscription Order Management: Master data and basic functions

As part of this new release, we’re excited to introduce SAP Best Practice Content (7WB). This scope item is a curated, pre-configured library of recommendable business processes, master data, configurations, and test scripts tailored for Subscription Order Management. This content will help our customers and partners to jump-start implementations with industry-aligned standards, reduce configuration effort, and leverage proven patterns rather than building everything from scratch.

We are further enhancing this scope item to include all critical business processes — and these enhancements are already part of our roadmap, so stay tuned!

The following capabilities are included with this release:

  • Create organizational structure and master data setup required for the creation of a subscription order.
  • Create a subscription order with the Internal Sales Representative role using subscription products including a multilevel advanced variant configuration BOM.
  • Transfer of a subscription contract to the follow-up system (such as SAP Convergent Invoicing) through the Order Distribution I­­nterface (ODI).
  • Replication will trigger the creation of a billing plan and generation of recurring and one-time charge billable items (BITs) for the subscription contract, as configured in SAP Convergent Invoicing.
  • In Convergent Invoicing, trigger the billing and invoicing of the billable items.
  • Display the new subscription contract details on the Subscription Contract Lifecycle Management Fiori app.

For more information about this new scope item, refer to New Scope Item for Subscription Order Management - 7WB on the SAP Help Portal.

Other Enhancements

In addition to the features mentioned above, Subscription Order Management 2025 FPS00 also introduces the following enhancements:

Rerating of Shared Allowances

Shared allowances have been a part of SOM since the SAP S/4HANA 1909 FPS01 release. However, until now, the process of re-rating shared allowances wasn’t supported. With this release, we’ve now enabled the re-rating of subscriptions contracts with shared allowances.

You can now perform end-to-end re-rating in both Convergent Invoicing (CI) and SAP Convergent Charging (SAP CC). To ensure accuracy, the entire sharing group is re-rated together when a re-rating is triggered, which means that all contracts linked to that group are automatically recalculated to ensure accuracy and consistency across the board.

Prerequisites:

  • Only the same business partner is allowed for all contracts within a sharing group; but account split is possible.
  • Only a single contributor contract (contract that creates a shared allowance) is supported within a sharing group.

 

Navigation from Fiori to Entitlement Management (EMS)

We have further enhanced the integration and user experience between SAP Subscription Order Management (SOM) and SAP Entitlement Management (EMS).

Users can now seamlessly navigate from the Fiori apps for Subscription Contract Lifecycle Management (F6193, F6487) directly to the related EMS Entitlement.

From the Fiori ‘Open In’ menu, simply select ‘Display Entitlements’ — this action will open the corresponding EMS document in a new browser tab, providing a smooth and integrated user experience across the BRIM and EMS landscape.

Figure 4: Fiori Navigation to related EMS entitlement

Improvements in Mass Processing Apps

In the SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS0 release, we introduced the Mass Changes of Subscription Contracts and Manage Mass Change Processing Fiori apps.

With the SAP S/4HANA 2025 FPS00 release, the mass processing apps are now even more powerful, flexible, and efficient. You may find more details about the initial release of these Fiori apps in our blog, What's New in Subscription Order Management 2023 FPS00.

Here’s a quick look at some of the key enhancements and new capabilities introduced in this release:

Improvements – Fiori App Mass Changes of Subscriptions F7405

Extended selection limits – The Mass Changes of Subscriptions app allows you to choose all the subscription contracts that you want to change and take them over into a mass processing. However, there were certain restrictions from Fiori for the number of contracts that can be selected. Based on the feedback from our customers, we extended the app to enable a larger number of contract selection in a single selection and you can also add these contracts in a single mass processing.

 

Improvements – Fiori App Manage Mass Processing of Subscription F7406

  • You can now select and schedule a mass processing directly from the search screen, allowing you to trigger multiple mass processing runs simultaneously.

Figure 5 Improvements in Fiori App Manage Mass Processing of Subscription F7406

 

  • Number of Total Requests in a List Report – You can now view the number of items contained in a mass processing. You can even set a filter on this calculated key figure, to identify mass processing runs based on their size.

Figure 6 Improvements – view number of total requests in the Fiori App Manage Mass Processing of Subscription F7406

Other notable improvements are:

  • A new change process for updating the CCM version
  • Improved UX with an enhanced header section that showcases a more comprehensive KPI structure and a new processing status for background processing.
  • The mass processing run has been transferred to the Background Processing Framework (bgPF) for an improved transactional consistency and control, stability and asynchronous execution.

For more information about this new feature, refer to App Details: Mass Changes of Subscriptions on the SAP Help Portal.

entry.title: Implementing SAP Emarsys Loyalty Management – Part 2 (Technical Deep Dive)
entry.content:
In Part 1, of this series, we explored how SAP Emarsys Loyalty Management addresses modern‐loyalty demands by going far beyond traditional point-schemes. We reviewed how loyalty programs are evolving into personalised, omnichannel experiences—and how Emarsys enables brands to design tiers, define actions and rewards, unify customer profiles across touchpoints, and engage members through highly relevant communications.

With that foundational business and functional outlook established, this article now moves into the technical implementation journey, explaining how the architecture, integrations and processes come together to make these business capabilities operational.

 

Prerequisites

To successfully implement SAP Emarsys Loyalty Management, ensure the following components and configurations are in place across the connected SAP landscape.

  SAP Emarsys and Loyalty

  • Unique Identifier for contacts
  • Smart Insight setup
  • Automation program to create and assign Loyalty HashID
  • Loyalty plan configuration (tiers, actions, and benefits)
  • Voucher setup (optional)
  • Loyalty Wallet (standard SDK-based or custom via Loyalty APIs)
  • Automation program to trigger Webhook on loyalty point confirmation events

   SAP S/4HANA

  • Sales data posting integration
  • GL accounts and controlling objects
  • Settlement and clearing logic
  • REST APIs for financial posting for the accruals and redemption scenario

 

Technical Architecture

 

 

Customer Registration and Loyalty Onboarding

Customer registration and loyalty onboarding begin when users join the program to enjoy rewards from their purchases and activities.
New customers can enrol during registration, while existing customers can join the program anytime. For both scenarios, a unique HashID must be generated and assigned to their record before enrolment.

The onboarding process can be initiated across mobile apps, websites, or POS systems.

Typically, SAP Sales Cloud or SAP S/4HANA act as the primary sources of customer data, which are then replicated to SAP Emarsys via SAP CPI.

When a new contact is registered, the record is first created in Sales Cloud or S/4HANA and then replicated to Emarsys. Once created, an automation program generates a HashID and stores it in a custom field at the contact level. Afterward, a Join API call is triggered to add the contact to the relevant Loyalty Plan.

For existing customers who join the loyalty program later, ensure that their HashID is already generated before executing the Join API call.

 

 

Points Accrual

The points accrual process enables customers to earn loyalty points and benefits based on their purchases and other qualifying activities. For purchase-based accruals, sales data flows from SAP S/4HANA (or ERP) to Smart Insight and then to Emarsys Loyalty, where points and benefits are automatically calculated according to the customer’s plan and tier.

Once points are confirmed, they are sent back to SAP S/4HANA for financial posting, ensuring accounting accuracy.

S/4HANA periodically sends sales transaction data to Emarsys through a tenant-specific Sales Data Load URL found under Predict → Data Sources → Sales Data in Emarsys. Once Emarsys receives the data, it calculates points based on the predefined logic.

An automation program triggers a webhook on the loyalty_points_from_purchase_confirmed event, which calls a CPI endpoint. This endpoint posts accrual entries in SAP S/4HANA, crediting customer accounts and updating liability GLs as per company-specific financial configurations.

 

 

Points Redemption

At checkout, customers can redeem their earned loyalty points either by paying directly with points or by using a voucher. Redemption can be initiated via mobile apps or websites during a purchase.

If the customer chooses to pay directly with points, the Remove Points API is called to deduct the required amount from their balance. A “Points Removed” activity is automatically recorded in their Emarsys profile.

Alternatively, customers can claim a voucher using the Claim Voucher API. Once the voucher code is generated, it can be applied at checkout. When a voucher is redeemed, the equivalent points are deducted, and a “Points Redeemed” activity is logged in Emarsys.

The financial postings for redemptions are handled by the respective sales channel (web, mobile, or POS) and then pushed to SAP S/4HANA via CPI to ensure accurate accounting entries.

 

 

Loyalty Segmentation, Personalization, and Campaigns

Effective segmentation and personalization are key to increasing engagement and retention. SAP Emarsys enables marketers to create segments using relational data templates, combining loyalty attributes (tier, points, activity type, or benefits) with contact and behavioral data.

The relational data connection can be setup easily by referring the help link “ Setting up Loyalty RDS connection” and templates can be setup as mentioned in the link  “ Setting up Loyalty segment templates”

These segments can be used across multiple campaign channels, including email, SMS, push, and web. Personalization tokens dynamically adapt campaign messages to show details such as the customer’s name, tier, available points, or next reward milestone.

 

  Personalization and Campaign Execution

  Once segments are built, they can be used across multiple channels — email, SMS, push notifications, or web campaigns.
  Using personalization tokens, each campaign message can dynamically adapt to display the customer’s name, tier, available points, or next reward milestone, delivering a truly personalized experience.

  SAP Emarsys offers prebuilt email template blocks designed for loyalty-related communications. Upon activation of a loyalty plan, the system automatically generates the relevant loyalty tokens. Furthermore, whenever a new Action or voucher is created, corresponding personalization tokens are generated by default.

  By blending loyalty data with Emarsys campaign automation, businesses can drive:

  • Higher engagement through relevant messaging
  • Increased redemption and repeat purchase rates
  • Stronger customer retention and satisfaction
     

 

 

Loyalty Reports and Dashboards

Analytics play a critical role in measuring loyalty program performance. SAP Emarsys publishes loyalty data to Google Cloud Platform through Open Data Views. These can be connected to SAP Datasphere using the Remote Table option for near real-time data access.

Within SAP Datasphere, organizations can model data, define KPIs (such as Total Points Accrued vs. Redeemed or Active Members by Tier), and then visualize insights using SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) dashboards.

This seamless data flow — from Emarsys to GCP, Datasphere, and SAC — provides real-time visibility into loyalty KPIs, helping businesses make data-driven decisions and optimize customer engagement strategies.

Summary

In Part 2, we explored the technical implementation journey of SAP Emarsys Loyalty Management — covering end-to-end integration, automation flows, financial postings, customer service enablement, campaign personalization, and analytical insights through SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud.

Stay tuned for Part 3, where we will focus on Customer Service and Support Scenarios in greater detail.
